website_summaries.verdict: This ricer works well for things such as gnocchi, and gets high marks for its easy to use handles.
pros: Long handles have silicone grips and good leverage
Hopper is 4" in diameter, and 2 3/4" deep
Works great for making gnocchi and mash, among other dishes
cons: Some claim that the metal used to construct this is flimsy and breaks easily

customer_reviews.title: No Lumps, Ever
customer_reviews.text: Sturdy, well made and easy to use. Potatoes don't push out around the sides. Good sized "pot". They all go through the bottom holes. Don't buy the ones with the holes around the cylinder. They just don't do as good/efficient a job as this one with the holes on the bottom only. Yes, it's true even though you'd think the opposite.
customer_reviews.author: Martin H JacobyTop Contributor: Cooking

customer_reviews.title: Simple, functional, easy to clean, too!
customer_reviews.text: Had been reading how using a ricer made the perfect "mashed" potatoes. They aren't kidding! I always used my hand mixer but wanted to try a ricer. This one is well made and does exactly what I wanted it to do. Won't ever use anything else!! A little side note... after boiling and draining potatoes, put them back in the hot pan and let them dry out. Put through the ricer, add milk, butter, seasonings... BEST mashed potatoes EVER!! = )
customer_reviews.author: Susan

customer_reviews.title: Perfect mashed potatoes
customer_reviews.text: Replaced a 20-something year old potato ricer that was getting really old, rattly, loose, a little rusty and a lot wobbly. Wow... We we had been fighting with the old one for so many years and forgot how smooth a new one operates! The "pot rest" on the opposite side of the handle makes it even easier and more comfortable for one person to load and operate when ricing a big Thanksgiving-sized batch of potatoes. Hope to get another 20+ years out of this one. Let's face it, in 20 years riced food will probably be a mealtime staple with me anyway.. ;-)
customer_reviews.author: Snowbound

customer_reviews.title: No LUMPS
customer_reviews.text: My wife actually ordered this and used for our Christmas dinner with our extended family. She made over 7 lbs. of potatoes for her now "famous" among the family potatoes and she loved the ricer and wished she had ordered one sooner. It made for the smoothest potatoes ever - no lumps at all. It will be even better for smaller batches of mashed potatoes.
customer_reviews.author: Russel G

customer_reviews.title: Don’t buy this ricer.
customer_reviews.text: I used this item one time and was very frustrated. It feels very cheap and flimsy to me and I was surprised when I took it out of the box. I think this item is over priced and I’m sorry I purchased it. I’ve had riicers before that were much better quality. I read many reviews before purchasing the celebrity chef one and am so disappointed. I feel like I totally wasted my money.
customer_reviews.author: Jean B.Eselgroth

customer_reviews.title: It really works!!!
customer_reviews.text: Perfect!!! I've watched quite a few videos lately that use a Potato Ricer to make amazing mashed potatoes and let me tell you - it's totally worth it! I put medium sized, cooked and unpeeled potatoes in the Ricer, pushed the handle down and out came the potatoes with the skin stuck to the plunger, making it super easy to remove the skin. I can't wait to use the Ricer to make other recipes, it's so easy to use and clean. I just wish I hadn't waited so long to buy one! The seller is also great, I appreciate such courteous and professional people. Thank you!!!
customer_reviews.author: StarlaBathory

customer_reviews.title: Good Quality and Easy to Use
customer_reviews.text: I use this potato ricer for making mashed potatoes; when I used an electric hand mixer I ended up with gluey mashed potatoes. I found a recipe that recommended using a potato ricer. It works! I just put the cooked potatoes through this potato ricer, add milk, butter, seasonings and stir it all up with a fork or spatula. It makes the best textured fluffy mashed potatoes. It is also very a sturdy product and easy to use.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Make mashed potatoes with better texture and flavor
customer_reviews.text: I used to make mashed potatoes with a potato masher by hand and my family liked them fine but i decided to try this ricer. I made a side by side comparison and the potatoes made with the ricer won hands down. Better texture for sure, but they even tasted better (don't know why or how.) I'm partially disabled and it takes a lot out of me to make a meal for my family but I love to do it, so when I do I want to make the best meal I can and this product helps me do that. I am very pleased with this purchase.
customer_reviews.author: L. Payton

customer_reviews.title: Works but Feels Not So Sturdy
customer_reviews.text: My friend likes a potato ricer and I bought this one. It seems a bit flimsy compared to hers. It takes a lot of force to push the boiled potatoes through the sieve holes and I feel like I am going to break the ricer. Also, some of the potato gets forced around the outside of the pusher plate and squeezes up onto the top of the pusher plate. This makes a mess. The gap between pusher plate and inner wall of chamber is too wide.
customer_reviews.author: W. Wight

customer_reviews.title: While I like a little lump and even some skin in my ...
customer_reviews.text: This is what I finally needed to make smooth, creamy mashed potatoes. While I like a little lump and even some skin in my mashed potatoes, my wife does not. She likes to whip them to smooth them out, but this always tends to make them into a nice rendition of spackle. This ricer requires a little arm strength and a little forethought in prep time, since it takes a lot longer to rice potatoes than to just mash/whip them. However, this is totally worth it since, in the end, you'll get perfectly creamy and sumptuous potatoes. Just add some whole milk or heavy cream and ample butter to the riced potatoes, then stir for perfect potatoes.
customer_reviews.author: MB

customer_reviews.title: When it failed we hunted on line for a better, stronger model we found the PriorityChef
customer_reviews.text: We've used potato ricers for many years, mostly the antiques found at auction. A few years ago we found a new one at IKEA. When it failed we hunted on line for a better, stronger model we found the PriorityChef. We've had it several months and use it daily. It is built better, stronger, with longer handles for more leverage. This one is the best!!!
customer_reviews.author: Richard L. Hilgers

customer_reviews.title: Great ricer that fits the bill!!!
customer_reviews.text: Never used a ricer before but now that I have tried one I love it!!! It only can fit small potatoes but that is fine with me since I use small Russet potatoes anyway. It easily riced the potatoes and did leave some potatoes behind in the hopper but from what I understand that is common with ricer's anyway. Now if someone can finger out how to make potatoes taste great without salt and butter; husband cannot have sodium nor fat in his food that would be a miracle. Nice weight, feels sturdy, nice quality cleaned up easily. I think this ricer will serve me well for many years to come.
customer_reviews.author: Val C

customer_reviews.title: Perfect!
customer_reviews.text: I bought a potato ricer from Ikea after my mom's rusted and I had to throw it. The one from Ikea bent after about the 3rd time I used it. So disappointed. But I love my riced potatoes, so finally spent twice the money on this one, and boy, am I happy! I love that this one has holes only on the bottom, as that is WAY less messy. This is strong, sturdy, easy to press, and I highly recommend spending more money on this one than on taking your chances with a cheaper one. I LOVE THIS RICER!
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Cheap materials, broke after six uses
customer_reviews.text: We bought this wanting to get some proper mashed potatoes, and while it worked, it actually did do as advertised; you put the cooked potatoes in, you get fluffy, riced potatoes. That said, when the ring around the ricer basket completely breaks while you're using it, and the ricer has only been used about six times if so much - it's not as if we need to make mashed potatoes all that often - there is a problem here. Now we have a completely unusable ricer after getting barely any form of use.
customer_reviews.author: Kindle Customer

customer_reviews.title: This Ricer is a wonderful replacement and I am now a convert
customer_reviews.text: I used to make mashed potatoes using my Kitchenaid mixer or a masher for smaller batches. This Ricer is a wonderful replacement and I am now a convert! It is very easy to use, faster cleanup. I bought this mainly for making baby food (avocados, bananas, sweet potatoes, squash, green peas, steamed apples, carrots, chayotes, hard boiled eggs, etc). I bought a 1 qt steamer along with this Ricer. I will be taking it with me on our family travels and still be able to provide healthy eating for the family.
customer_reviews.author: JVelarmino

customer_reviews.title: Be strong if you buy this!
customer_reviews.text: Unless you work out each day or naturally have strong hands this is not for you. It takes quite a bit of lower arm strength and hand strength to operate this gadget. It works for me but the mill type is easier to use. The construction does not lead me to think it will last long, but time will tell.
customer_reviews.author: pj

customer_reviews.title: Hated it
customer_reviews.text: If u want mash potatoes for 1-2 people, maybe this would be ok. Horrible for 8people’s worth. This was sooo messy. It was hard mechanically to put enough pressure on the river to make the potatoes come out. It is a slow, arduous process and I will never do it again. All the chefs says a “ricer” is the best flavored mash potatoes. I call BS. Back to a mixer next time. Too much effort, too much mess, takes way too much time to do mashed potatoes with this contraption.
customer_reviews.author: RJL

customer_reviews.title: Doesn't work
customer_reviews.text: This ricer operates by using leverage to press a disc against the food to be riced, pushing it through tiny holes at the far end of a cylinder. Unfortunately the disk is smaller than the inside of the cylinder and as much food gets squeezed out backwards as gets through the holes. This backed up food then needs to be removed and placed back in the cylinder. Using this device is very laborious. However, if you're into making hash browns, this ricer is perfect for expressing the water out of your potatoes after you have grated and rinsed them.
customer_reviews.author: G. Rogers

customer_reviews.title: Pretty much as described and pieces fit together  well.
customer_reviews.text: Used this once. Potatoes were smooth with no lumps and seemed to have more fluff when compared to mixer whipped. The stainless steel has a polished finish and the ricer appears sturdy. We will try it on cauliflower next.
customer_reviews.author: Allan Walker

customer_reviews.title: Very Sturdy, Great Seal.
customer_reviews.text: Well made. Stainless. Feels sturdy. Most importantly seals very well. No superheated potato juices come flying from the lid, which a problem with cheap versions.
customer_reviews.author: Askani

customer_reviews.title: Pain in the ass to use!!!
customer_reviews.text: I bought this because I saw a YouTube video and they used it to make “the best mashed potatoes”. This thing is a pain in the ass, potatoes mushed you the side and it’s a pain in the ass to clean. Save your money and just use a potatoes masher or an electric mixer.
customer_reviews.author: Susan K. Aschoff

customer_reviews.title: Simple to use and clean
customer_reviews.text: This is a one-potato-at-a-time ricer. The basket is a nice size for everyday use. For 7 pounds of potatoes it takes a while. But it is smaller to store than my old huge one. If you use the rubber-like part on the end to lean on a pot while ricing it may bend. I found leaning on the pot as near to the basket as possible was less likely to bend it. For the price it is a good buy. Cleans in dishwasher. Note: it does not come apart for cleaning.
customer_reviews.author: rustyredcab

customer_reviews.title: Very sturdy
customer_reviews.text: Never owned a potato ricer before and was sick of eating lumpy mashed potatoes (although lumpy potatoes was pretty trendy in the late 50’s and early 60’s) so I made this purchase. It is very sturdy and nicely made and using it — the potatoes I made were perfect.
customer_reviews.author: Mary R.

customer_reviews.title: Not a perfect fit
customer_reviews.text: My only complaint about this product is the plunger doesn't drop into the ricer very precisely, causing up to a fifth of the contents to be pushed out the sides. A slightly more ergonomic/imaginative design might have prevented this problem, but would probably be larger as a result. As is, it is a perfectly usable tool that makes mashing potatoes (or avocados) much faster and more consistent.
customer_reviews.author: Zaky-Bear

customer_reviews.title: Item works as advertised
customer_reviews.text: The item works as advertised, however I must admit I really wanted to make my favorite desert "spaghetti ice" and the ice cream tends to come through the sides of the press. If this was a little better sealed whether it be a tighter fit or gasket perhaps, this wouldn't happen. I'm confident that it works for its intended purpose but was hoping for it to meet my intended use. Overall well made item for the price.
customer_reviews.author: Ken

customer_reviews.title: Used and russty product
customer_reviews.text: just opened the package. The product is dirty and russty.
customer_reviews.author: Janet

customer_reviews.title: Too expensive and a little wonky.
customer_reviews.text: This product was overpriced for what it is. I don't care for the design of the round part that smashes our potatoes. Potatoes get stuck on it and then end up making a mess. I should have just purchased a food mill instead. I wanted this because it was smaller, but it does take a while to do a lot of potatoes. If you are only making a few potatoes then it isn't bad. I would not purchase it again. It did however make our potatoes extra smooth and creamy.
customer_reviews.author: Juli

customer_reviews.title: Its Awesome
customer_reviews.text: This is sturdy and easy to use. I wanted the potato ricer more to up my game in the kitchen! I wanted to improve my potato pancakes and gnocchi. This device is super sturdy and I can see why reviews of other devices have complained about bending the handles. This one is super tough. Definitely worth it.
customer_reviews.author: JK

customer_reviews.title: Poorly made will break, aluminum not stainless steel
customer_reviews.text: Flimsy and poorly made put in 2 soft red potatoes after boiling for 2 hours and the metal bent and this is made of aluminum not stainless steel as mentioned.
customer_reviews.author: Jess

customer_reviews.title: Took the to the next level
customer_reviews.text: My wife's mashed potatoes have always been outstanding. I didn't think they could be improved. But she saw this being used on a cooking show, and we decided to get it. We all agreed that it resulted in mashed potatoes that were fluffier and even better than before. This ricer is well made and feels solid. It requires a bit of muscle, but the results are well worth it. It definitely lives up to its hype and good reviews.
customer_reviews.author: Paul

customer_reviews.title: Quality and Easy to Use
customer_reviews.text: This is my first potato ricer and I read through many reviews of other products. I am really pleased with the one I picked. Many other gave the removable discs and other reviews said that this was a problem. I love that this is all one piece! It was super easy to clean. Best part- it made my potatoes rice beatifully! Which I needed to make gnocchi. No doubt- this is the ricer you want.
customer_reviews.author: Terra Heywood

customer_reviews.title: no more lumps!
customer_reviews.text: Always unhappy with my mashed potatoes as after really putting my muscles into mashing potatoes with the old masher, there would still be small lumps. This ricer produces small thin ribbons of mashed potatoes and no lumps at all. The only thing that I do not find easy is opening the ricer after you have pushed a potato through it - often stuck shut and requires significant force to re-open to add the next potato.
customer_reviews.author: Brit in Asheville

customer_reviews.title: It does work but not super easy to clean
customer_reviews.text: As a potato ricer this one works fine. Some of the potato doesn't get pushed through the wholes but pops out the top and sides of the press. As for making super creamy mashed potatoes this won't do it I had to hit it with the stick blender after anyway.
customer_reviews.author: Gerald H.

customer_reviews.title: love it. I rinse it immediately after use
customer_reviews.text: I never had one of these before, love it. Put the potato in, squeeze, then i used a spoon or fork to mix in the salt and butter, no masher needed, quick, easy, and effortless, and no lumps. One of the reason why i bought it was because I was trying to drain water from spinach for a recipe, i used a ton of paper towels and thought there had to be an easier way. I googled it, and peopled recommended using one of these, but i have not tried using it for that yet. I will update when i do. It may be hard to clean if you do not rinse immediately.
customer_reviews.author: CJ

customer_reviews.title: What a difference this makes!
customer_reviews.text: We have been wanting to get one of these for a long time, and now we don't know how we went this long without it! We have only tried it with potatoes, but you can use it for lots of other things too. It cranked out the smoothest mashed taters we ever had, so it lives up to what it promises to do.
customer_reviews.author: The Bas

customer_reviews.title: Easy to use
customer_reviews.text: Easy to use. Be sure to clean before the first use. There was some sort of black residue coating the small holes when I took it out of the box
customer_reviews.author: Naomi

customer_reviews.title: well made, but hard to use
customer_reviews.text: Arrived in very good condition. Unfortunately I found it too hard to press down, so had to return.
customer_reviews.author: SZ

customer_reviews.title: I learned it was also a great way to make mashed potatoes
customer_reviews.text: I have never owned a potato ricer before, but purchased one so that I could make homemade gnocchi. Once I received the ricer, I learned it was also a great way to make mashed potatoes. I have not yet attempted the gnocchi, but I have used the ricer for mashed potatoes, and it works great. The mashed potatoes were smooth and fluffy. The ricer itself is easy to use and easy to clean. I'm very happy with this purchase and would buy from this company again.
customer_reviews.author: K. Dietry

customer_reviews.title: perfect for preparing spinach for recipes
customer_reviews.text: I use this ricer for squeezing the water out of spinach when using frozen spinach for recipes. The ricer works great and makes the job much quicker and easier. The quality of the product is excellent and it is very well designed and ergonomic. It is long-about 12 inches- but not bulky--but it does require some place to store.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Great Product!!!
customer_reviews.text: I read most of the reviews of several potato ricers featured on the Amazon site. This Priority Masher seemed to have consistently better reviews than the other ricers and fewer one star reviews. This product lives up to the best reviews. I'm having fun! Try riced hard boiled egg, boiled potato and Gorgonzola Cheese! Amazing....
customer_reviews.author: KZ

customer_reviews.title: Ok but not great
customer_reviews.text: This is a decent potato ricer for the price. It's not super sturdy and the Piston doesn't fit too tight. So you get alot of potatoes getting forced back out of the top. For occasional use it's fine. Not something I would want to use often though.
customer_reviews.author: daniel

customer_reviews.title: Excellent Ricer
customer_reviews.text: I hesitated buying a ricer for years. My friend convinced me I needed one to get perfect mashed potatoes, she was right. I looked at several and settled on the Priority Chef, it is very high quality, heavyweight gauge stainless steel. It is easy to rice potatoes and the outcome is fantastic. I highly recommend this product.
customer_reviews.author: E. Badger

customer_reviews.title: A great gadget
customer_reviews.text: I bought this ricer mainly for squeezing the water out of frozen spinach. It works beautifully. I had the spinach ready for a recipe in minutes. It works simply -- drop food in, squeeze, presto -- you're done. Cleans easily.
customer_reviews.author: scottsdale zinner

customer_reviews.title: Works well
customer_reviews.text: Silky smooth potatoes, at last. I had used this once, and the potatoes turned out grainy. I think it was just the potatoes themselves. It was really tough to push them through. I used it again last night, and it was simple to push them through this time. Once I got them 'riced' I used a masher to basically stir in the milk and butter. The potatoes had zero lumps, and a smooth mouth feel, without being too fluffy. Glad I made a lot - I may have some now.
customer_reviews.author: KY Jamz

customer_reviews.title: Super Ricer!!
customer_reviews.text: I have always wanted a ricer so I got it right before thanksgiving for my mashed potatoes. This is one of the best things I have ever got for my kitchen. The mashed potatoes were to die for, so light and creamy!
customer_reviews.author: Cyd

customer_reviews.title: I love this thing!!
customer_reviews.text: Money well spent! This thing makes the best mashed potatoes- and so easy! I can't wait to try it on other foods... bet it would work well for wringing out frozen spinach! The item shipped and arrived quickly and I even got an email from the seller when it shipped, which is rare. Very satisfied customer, I'll definitely be recommending this to my friends.
customer_reviews.author: Moglo

customer_reviews.title: One Star
customer_reviews.text: Cheap and not worth the money. Tried to rice cooked cauliflower and it was impossible to use.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: DIFFICULT TO OPERATE
customer_reviews.text: I loved the texture of the potatoes, but I found the equipment very stiff and hard to push the potatoes through. I was worn out after this exercise. Wish it were easier. Outside of this problem, it is a very nice sturdy piece of equipment. Ruth Stein
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Great tool
customer_reviews.text: I use it to mush the boiled potatoes that I use to make Gnocchi's Works well for smaller batches. I have an other machine I use for larger potato mashing projects. This unit is easy to wash and keep clean.
customer_reviews.author: Tommaso Candiano

customer_reviews.title: Rubber on the handle helps with grip
customer_reviews.text: While swapping dessert recipes with my co-worker, she suggested a recipe replacing sweet potatoes with yams but "use a ricer". I didn't even know what a ricer was and once I found out on Amazon, I ordered Priority Chef because of the handle. And, I'm glad I did. One recipe calls to mash the potatoes and it helps having a rubber around the handles. I don't have a strong grip and every little thing helps. I highly recommend the Priority Chef Potato Ricer and Masher. It can be use on carrots (which I used), yams and all sorts of root crops.
customer_reviews.author: Gladstone Frau

customer_reviews.title: Love It
customer_reviews.text: I love it. I’ve never used a ricer before. It makes much better mashed potatoes than a masher. A lot more fun to use. I riced Kukon Golds that I boiled quartered with the peels on. The peels slipped off as the potatoes riced.
customer_reviews.author: Jeandot

customer_reviews.title: Decent Potato Ricer, NOT  REAL 18/10 Stainless Steel!
customer_reviews.text: I am a professional chef and I love 18/10 stainless steel for all my kitchen appliances and utensils. This is NOT 18/10 quality!! No where on the box or the potato ricer itself says it's 18/10 (look for labels on the bottom marked "18/10 stainless steel" for true 18/10 quality products). Besides the false advertisement here, the ricer operates very decently compared to most conventional ricers. The ricer is weighted nicely, easy to press, cleaning was simple, and overall a good potato ricer. It is a little annoying that food still squishes up on the sides of the food press, but these handheld models will do that regardless over a food mill.
customer_reviews.author: Klyftonite

customer_reviews.title: Hand tools have a place...
customer_reviews.text: Easy to use but more importantly, easy to clean. Motorized choppers, graters, mixers and processors are great if you're preparing a lot of food and maybe have three or four sinks. Otherwise, the food processor becomes the "elephant in the kitchen" waiting to be cleaned and put away with all those parts in the dedicated cabinet where it awaits the next banquet. When you're done preparing light, fluffy mashed potatoes with the Priority Chef Potato Ricer (yes, a little muscle is needed) soak it in a sudsy sink or toss it in the dishwasher. You can't do that with a food processor.
customer_reviews.author: Mrs. George Smith

customer_reviews.title: One Star
customer_reviews.text: Very hard to push through - I have returned it..
customer_reviews.author: Catherine M. Shannon

customer_reviews.title: It looked great, just what I ordered
customer_reviews.text: I ordered this product about a month ago and promptly went out of town. It looked great, just what I ordered. Today was the first time I've had an opportunity to use it, and I'm in love! I made Duchess potatoes and I'll never mash potatoes any other way again. I didn't realize that my potatoes were a little gummy when I used a mixer until I tasted these riced potatoes. Thank you Priority Chef!
customer_reviews.author: Kitty

customer_reviews.text: factory Black residue after numerous washes still will not go away. I washed with detergent, & then 90% isopropyl alcohol, & i am atill geting black residue on the paper towel after 10 wipes. I am considering returning, this is unacceptable for a food preparation utensil.

customer_reviews.title: World's better than my mom's old rusty handmedown.
